newsitem.title: UK: U.S. stocks in London static, eye volatile dollar.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks in London static, eye volatile dollar.

text.p: U.S. shares were little changed on Thursday from Wall Street's closing prices as current volatility in the currency markets kept many European investors away, dealers said.
"The swings in the dollar have killed the market today. We've had very little business," one dealer said.
The U.S. currency charged higher in Europe on Thursday to stand near 116 yen by 1030 GMT, up over two yen from late Wednesday.
Against the German mark, the dollar eased off its highs to stand at 1.6921/26 against earlier peaks just above 1.70.

Only a handful of shares had traded by late morning. AT&T Corp was up $1/8 to $34-3/4 after Chairman Robert Allen told shareholders at the company's annual meeting on Wednesday that boosting the phone giant's flagging stock price was management's highest priority.

AT&T shares, which closed at a 12-month low of $30.75 on April 24, gained 37.50 cents to end Wednesday's session at $34.625. The stock has underperformed the S&P 500 by around 55 percent over the past 52 weeks, according to data from Reuters Securities 3000.
But historic comparisons are complicated due to the 1996 divestiture of Lucent Technologies Inc. and NCR Corp, AT&T's former equipment and computer arms.
AT&T stock remains the most widely held publicly listed stock in the U.S., with more than 3.3 million shareholders owning about 1.6 billion shares, according to a company spokesman.

Boeing Corp was up $1/4 to $102-3/4 after the company said on Wednesday that it remained confident that its planned merger with McDonnell Douglas Corp would be completed this summer despite formal objections from the European Commission.
The June S&P 500 futures contract was down 0.40 to 842.55 while the June T-bond eased 2/32 to 109-7/32.
